race.name: BELGIAN WAFFLE RIDE SAN DIEGO
race.tagline: The OG American Spring Classic. 130 miles of kasseien-crushing brutality where 1 in 3 riders DNF, and the survivors earn their waffles.

vitals.venue: Del Mar Polo Fields at Surf Sports Park
vitals.address: 14989 Via De La Valle, 92014, San Diego, CA

logistics.explanation: San Diego International Airport is only 25 miles from Del Mar with easy freeway access, but race day execution suffers from bottlenecks. Yun reports "With 1,500 riders rolling out together, we got caught behind bottlenecks on early singletrack—losing nearly 45 minutes before the race even really began." The venue itself (Del Mar Polo Fields) provides ample parking, though course management struggles with field size logistics.

length.explanation: At 131 miles with 12,000 ft of climbing, BWR sits firmly in ultra-endurance territory. Yun finished "just under 13 hours," while others took 14+ hours to complete the course. Nick Leeper targeted "300 watts" for Double Peak but "couldn't push my target power" after 100+ miles in the saddle. The distance reflects annual route tweaks and the organizers' penchant for secrecy.

technicality.explanation: Pete Stetina observed the course evolution: "this year it was a gravel race with road sectors" rather than a road race with dirt. Yun noted "A brief trail section lifted our spirits, as did Keri's expertise in picking the best MTB lines." Nick Leeper chose 35c tires at 44 PSI but "didn't have a lot of cornering and braking confidence with the 35c tires on the loose over hard single track."

elevation.explanation: The 12,000 ft of climbing includes the notorious Double Peak placement in the final miles. Nick Leeper "couldn't push my target power of 300 watts" on the Double Peak climb, managing only "270 and getting passed more than I should have." The sadistic genius is timing—brutal climbing when legs are destroyed from 110+ miles. Yun described "endless steep hills, my legs protesting every 15–17% gradient with increasing rage."

climate.explanation: San Diego's May weather typically offers near-ideal conditions, but 2025 proved challenging. "Southern California received a lot of rain this year which rutted out the dirt and made it pretty rough," creating technical terrain issues. Yun noted "'At least the weather's cool,' I kept telling myself" during grey skies that were "perfect temps for hard riding without overheating."

altitude.explanation: Starting at Del Mar Polo Fields near sea level, the course climbs inland toward Palomar Mountain but doesn't reach sustained high altitude. The highest points in Highland Valley Road and Pamo Valley don't approach the 9,000+ ft threshold for significant oxygen impact. Most climbing occurs at moderate elevations throughout Southern California's coastal mountain terrain.

adventure.explanation: This delivers bucket-list gravel suffering across 23 "unroad sectors" through Southern California terrain. Yun and her partner were "two of just 21 women to finish the Waffle that day. Only about two-thirds of the 300 men finished." The course includes creek crossings, Death Valley sections, and Lusardi Switchbacks. Post-race features Belgian waffles and Lost Abbey beers for survivors.

prestige.explanation: BWR San Diego IS the original. The OG. The granddaddy that spawned an entire series across North America. It's the Queen Leg of the Quad-Tripel Crown and attracts the biggest names in gravel: Peter Stetina, Keegan Swenson, Alexey Vermeulen, Matt Beers. When Michael Marckx created this in 2012, he established a blueprint that the entire gravel world has tried to copy. 15 years of history and counting.

race_quality.explanation: Monuments of Cycling delivers professional race organization with multiple aid stations, though Yun noted "At Station 3, around mile 60, volunteers told us future aid stops might not be manned" due to the extreme conditions. The race includes timing chips, SAG support until cutoff, and full expo experience. Nick Leeper confirms they "provide a lot of support" throughout the challenging course.

experience.explanation: The combination of technical terrain, brutal climbing, and extreme attrition creates unforgettable suffering. Yun described sprinting "between cutoffs" with her partner, "determined to beat the 11:30 a.m. deadline." The weather impact made terrain "pretty rough," adding to the challenge. Only finishing earns access to the post-race Belgian celebration culture with actual waffles and craft beer.

community.explanation: BWR has cultivated a passionate tribe of 'kasseien-crushing winnaars' who return year after year. The Belgian classics heritage creates unique shared language and culture. However, the extreme difficulty (30-40% DNF) means this isn't the most welcoming entry point for gravel newbies. The community is tight but demands you earn membership through suffering. As Event History puts it: "It was 2011 when just 136 people showed up for the first ever Belgian Waffle Ride. What it was was anyone's guess."

field_depth.explanation: The field attracts elite gravel professionals and serious competitive riders. AbbottRacing and other elite-level participants compete alongside recreational riders like Julie Dunkle. The extreme difficulty creates natural selection—Yun notes "Only about two-thirds of the 300 men finished" in 2025. Power outputs like Nick Leeper's 440W efforts on early climbs demonstrate the competitive caliber required.

value.explanation: At $195+ for entry, BWR is premium priced but delivers premium value: full weekend festival, expo access, multiple aid stations, SAG support, timing chip, post-race waffles and finisher's beer. The 15-year prestige, quality production, and life-changing experience justify the cost. You're not just buying a race entry - you're buying access to gravel royalty.

expenses.explanation: Total trip cost is moderate for an elite event. San Diego has abundant accommodation options across price points. Flights to SAN are competitive from most US cities. Del Mar area isn't cheap but Escondido offers budget options. Figure $195 entry + $150-300/night hotel + $200-500 flights + food/misc. You can do BWR for under $1,000 total if you're smart, or splash out on beach resort recovery. Similar expense level to Leadville Trail 100 MTB.

crux_climb.name: Muur van Dubbelberg (Double Peak)
crux_climb.description: The sadistic final climb designed to crush dreams. Last 800 ft comes in final mile with 11% average gradient and 20%+ pitches.

technical_sections.name: Lake Hodges
technical_sections.character: Most technical section - rocky single-track, sandy sections

climbing_sections.name: Black Canyon
climbing_sections.profile: 11 miles to Mesa Grande toward Palomar Mountain

key_features.course_philosophy: A modern, irreverent cycling odyssey over Unroads of every flavor - dirt, gravel, single-track, double-track, and brutal asphalt - plus steep bergs, long climbs, creek crossings, and relentless headwinds. A twisted tribute to the legendary Belgian Spring Classics.

belgian_inspiration.kasseien_translation: Rocky dirt sectors and sandy washes substitute for Belgian cobblestones
belgian_inspiration.bergs_translation: Double Peak and canyon climbs substitute for Belgian short steep climbs

men.winner: Steve Klasna, Dave Jaeger, Brent Prenzlow (3-way tie)

black_pill_truths: 30-40% of starters DNF - roughly 1 in 3 people need to be picked up or find their own ride home
Average weekend warriors will NOT have fun on the Waffle - only the most prepared will triumph
Line choice is the #1 reason riders finish early with double flats feeling frustrated and deflated
Last year many participants took 14+ hours to finish - more than twice the elite time, finishing in the dark
The organizers deliberately placed the crux climb (20%+ gradients) in the final 10 miles after 110+ miles of racing
Technical skills are NOT optional - some sectors require walking if you can't handle single-track on 40mm tires
recommended_for: Experienced gravel racers seeking prestige event
Road cyclists with strong endurance looking to test gravel skills
Anyone wanting to tick off a bucket-list gravel event
Riders who want suffering followed by Belgian celebration culture
not_recommended_for: Pure road cyclists uncomfortable on dirt
Riders who can't handle 40mm+ tires on technical terrain

equipment_recommendations.tire_note: Wider tires (40mm+) strongly recommended for poor fitness or bike handling skills
equipment_recommendations.gearing: Must handle 20%+ gradient climbs - consider 34-34 or lower for Double Peak
equipment_recommendations.bike_type: Gravel bike optimal; cross bike with road gearing works; road bike possible but high flat risk

sources: Cyclingnews - Belgian Waffle Ride Series coverage
VeloNews - Monuments of Gravel: Belgian Waffle Ride
Source Endurance - BWR Survival Guide by Neil Shirley
The Hard Way Podcast - Michael Marckx Interview

final_verdict.one_liner: Belgian suffering translated to sunny San Diego, where Double Peak turns roadies into believers and flatlanders into casualties.
final_verdict.should_you_race: You need legitimate climbing legs and the patience to navigate technical single-track when you're already cooked. This isn't a pure gravel race—it's a Spring Classic with dirt sectors that'll shred tires and egos equally. Show up undertrained for Double Peak's 20% final pitches and you'll be walking in front of 2,800 witnesses.
final_verdict.alternatives: SBT GRVL offers similar distance with more consistent gravel and less traffic, while Unbound 200 delivers pure suffering without the roadie pretensions. If you want Spring Classic vibes without the California price tag, try Almanzo or Barry-Roubaix.

course_description.character: BWR San Diego masquerades as an American Belgian classic, trading cobblestones for bone-rattling dirt sectors and sandy washes across 23 off-road segments. You'll roll through 80 miles of pavement and 52 miles of 'unroad' — everything from rocky single-track at Lake Hodges to the infamous sandy traps of Bandy Canyon. The course saves its cruelest joke for last: Double Peak, a 4.5-mile climb that turns savage in the final mile when your legs are already cooked.

suffering_zones.label: Lake Hodges Technical
suffering_zones.desc: Rocky single-track and sandy sections that eat tires and punish the unfocused. Most technical terrain of the day when you're still feeling strong.

suffering_zones.label: Sandy Bandy Canyon
suffering_zones.desc: Sharp rocks and loose sand patches that grab wheels and destroy dreams. Also known as Raptor Ridge — the name tells you everything.

suffering_zones.label: Black Canyon Grind
suffering_zones.desc: Eleven miles of climbing toward Palomar's base on pure gravel. Beautiful scenery you won't appreciate while suffering.

suffering_zones.label: Elfin Forest Minefield
suffering_zones.desc: Final dirt section when fatigue makes every rock a potential race-ender. Ten miles from glory, infinite ways to blow up.

course_description.signature_challenge: The Muur van Dubbelberg — Double Peak's final mile averages 11% with 20-23% pitches when you've already climbed 10,500 feet. The last 800 feet of elevation come in that brutal final kilometer, forcing riders to 'paperboy' diagonally across the road just to keep moving. Your FTP means nothing here.

videos.title: Inside Belgian Waffle Ride 2025 | New Course, Fast Action, We're Back!
videos.description:
Belgian Waffle Ride is always an epic event. BWR has a new location this year which starts in Del Mar and featured a smaller but tight group of favorites from previous winners like Peter Stetina, Alexey Vermeulen and defending champ Matt Beers. This represents a new era in gravel cycling as riders are getting faster on and off the dirt and single track. Notable women include defending champ Sofia Gomez Villafane and Flavia Oliveira. It was an extremely fast race course that had the bicycle pushed to its limit. We always love covering our local bike race BWR. Did you do the event? How was your experience? Let us know in the comments!  


Editor: Michelle Liu
Photo: Kris Hull
Additional Footage: Avery Stumm
Thank you: Ed Philbrick, Michael Marckx

videos.title: BWR Wafer and Wanna: Belgian Waffle Ride California 2022
videos.description:
This is the 2022 BWR Wafer and the BWR Wanna in San Marcos, CA, from the perspective of average cyclists. Come experience the more attainable versions of the Belgian Waffle Ride from me while doing the BWR Wafer and from my dad while doing the the BWR Wanna. 

This is the perfect race for us to do together as it meets in the middle of our cycling interests and desire to cover miles. I generally prefer all terrain bicycle touring, and my dad generally prefers cross country mountain biking. 

Other than that, all you really need to know about the BWR is that instead of medals, finishers receive a celebratory bottle of beer. Oh, and who could forget the pre-race waffles and the post-race waffles with ice cream.

We're not sponsored, but we both really liked our bicycle setups, which were as follows:

Me: 
- Sonder Camino gravel bike (https://us.alpkit.com/collections/sonder-camino?storeRedirect=US) with the low end Shimano GRX group set (https://bike.shimano.com/en-EU/product/component/grx-10-speed.html)
-  Teravail Washburn 700 x 38 gravel-specific tires (https://teravail.com/products/washburn-tire?variant=39350969499699)
- Road Runner Bags Jammer Handlebar Bag (https://roadrunnerbags.us/products/the-jammer-bag)

My dad:
- Specialized Diverge Comp gravel bike (https://www.specialized.com/us/en/diverge-comp-e5/p/199975?color=322132-199975)

videos.title: Riding our bikes from San Diego to Monterey - The Belgian Otter Tour
videos.description:
Join us as we take in the California scenery and challenge ourselves on a multi-day bike tour from San Diego to Monterey.

An adventure of a lifetime, we started out the week by racing a tandem at Belgian Waffle Ride and then pedaled our way up the coast to hang out at the Sea Otter Classic bike festival. 

Ride Totals:
Distance: 474.8 miles
Elevation: 22,656 feet
Moving Time: 28 Hours 36 Minutes
Average Speed: 16.4 mph

Don't forget to subscribe to our channel to stay up to date with all of our cycling adventures, and let us know what you think in the comments below!

Check out our Belgian Waffle Ride Recap: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i0-AD4rMzhM

Connect with Us:
Website: https://www.performancebike.com/?utm_source=youtube&utm_medium=video
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/performancebike/?utm_source=youtube&utm_medium=video
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/performancebike/?utm_source=youtube&utm_medium=video

quotes.text: This is a brand new course to me. It's looking pretty exciting. It's going to favor the mountain bikers a little bit even though there's a fair amount of road. I think the decisive parts of the course always lend it to those with more experience in the off-road side of things.

The big news with this race this year is that there is a massive course change with the change in venue. We are no longer climbing double peak. Which is good because historically this race has finished up a massive climb with the steepest pitch being right at the end of the race up a road called Double Peak. It was brutal. But this year that is not how the race ends. Instead there's more gravel.

The course this year also included quite a bit more rough off-road sections, which meant more people considered it a gravel race instead of a road race with off-road sectors, which is usually how it's been treated in years past. The most obvious display of this was in tire choice. In years past, most riders opted for a wider road tire like the Strata Bianca 36s, however, this year, most riders were on 40s or 45s and opted for a more gravel specific tire.
